Award.AwardTitle: Space-Time from the Spectral Point of View: Towards Quantum Gravity
Award.AbstractNarration:
The most challenging problem in theoretical physics is the unification of the laws of quantum physics with Einstein's general theory of relativity. The ideas in this direction that have been pursued most forcefully are superstring theory and noncommutative geometry. These two approaches are intimately related. Noncommutative geometry has provided a new framework to study spaces which could not be handled by the standard methods of Riemannian geometry. It offered a new perspective in the study of gauge theories and the role of the Higgs field and is a promising candidate to describe geometries at Planckian energies. In the past years it has been established that space-time is approximated by a well defined product of a continuous four-dimensional manifold by a finite dimensional space. The main focus of this program is to construct a genuinely noncommutative finite dimensional space valid at sub-planckian scales and whose limit at lower energies is the noncommutative space of the standard model. The geometry will be reduced to those of almost commuting matrices, and it will be possible to get a handle on quantizing the geometry. It will also study new asymptotic limits of the spectral action as well as cosmological implications. Other parts of this project will study various aspects of gravity such as stability of BPS monopoles, and formulation of consistent massive theories of gravity, implications of the presence of right-handed neutrinos on the geometry of spacetime, the behavior of spectral actions in the presence of singularities and non-perturbative evolution of the dynamical fields at scales of the order of the Planck length.
Broader impact of Project: Due to its interdisciplinary nature, this work which involves research on the frontiers of noncommutative geometry, will be of benefit to both physicists and mathematicians. The new ideas and methods in this proposal will contribute to the knowledge of the high energy theory and phenomenology, quantum gravity and mathematics communities, and to a lesser extent to the astro-physics community. The American University of Beirut (AUB) plays a very important role in promoting the American educational system in the Middle East. Historically, the emphasis was on liberal education. The new aim is to provide in addition a vibrant environment for the promotion of research. The launching of the Ph.D. program in theoretical physics in October 2009 is a step in that direction and is attracting students of high caliber.

POR.DRECONTENT:
At the turn of the 20th century in a revolutionary work Einstein has shown that the presence of matter curves the four-dimensional space-time according to the rules of Riemannian geometry. The dynamics of the gravitational field is governed by Einstein equations which depend on the curvature of space-time and modify Newton's laws of gravitation in complete agreement with observations. Without the work of Riemann in the preceding century the correct Einstein equations for the gravitational field would not have been discovered. There are three other fundamental forces in nature. The electromagnetic, the weak and the strong nuclear forces. They govern the interactions of 48 elementary particles coming in repeating three families each with 16 chiral massless particles. These are the leptons  and quarks, the first family of which are the electrons, neutrinos and up and down quarks. The interactions are mediated by the W and Z gauge bosons and eight gluons. Masses for the fermions is made possible through a scalar Higgs doublet. This complicated structure does not follow from geometry. It is natural to look for a generalization of Riemannian geometry which explains all particles and their interactions. 

The work of von Neumann in the beginning of the 20th Century on the classification of operator algebras revealed the existence of a new geometry, which he named type III. This geometry was constructed in the ground breaking work of Alain Connes in 1978 for which he was awarded the Fields medal in mathematics. This is a new kind of geometry where coordinates are replaced with operators, and the metric with which distances are measured is replaced with a differential operator whose spectrum could be evaluated. The study of geometry becomes spectral in nature, and is very well suited to blend with quantum mechanics. A well posed question in mathematics is whether it is possible to hear the shape of the drum? In other words to reconstruct the geometry of the drum from the knowledge of the fundamental tones. Although this question was answered in the negative within Reimannian geometry, where mathematicians found counterexamples of manifolds having the same spectra, it has been recently shown by Alain Connes that the question has a positive answer when formulated in terms of the spectral data of noncommutative geometry. A similar question can then be asked of whether the observed spectrum of particles and their interactions could be used to determine the geometry of space-time. The aim of this project is to examine the hypothesis that all fundamental forces in nature as well as the particle spectrum result as a consequence of a geometric principle and define a noncommutative space-time. This is a grand unification generalization of Einstein's formulation of gravity as a geometric theory. In a long-term collaborative research with the mathematician Alain Connes we have identified the noncommutative space that produces the Standard Model unified with gravity. In addition, we have shown, under very weak assumptions, that the Standard Model with all its details and intricacies, comes out as an almost unique possibility after classifying all finite noncommutative spaces. In a tantalizing coincidence we have shown that a generalization of Heisenberg quantization condition on the volume of space-time would result in exactly the same noncommutative space which singles out the Standard model of particle interactions or a grand unified model first proposed by Pati and Salam in 1974, The volume quantization condition implies that the volume of space-time is an (even) integer multiple of a unit sphere of Planck volume. These Planck spheres constitute quanta of space-time. This work thus provides a convincing evidence that we have correctly identified the hidden structure of space-time in the form of a quantized noncommutative space. The spectrum of the Dirac operator, a first order differential operator on this space, give all geometric invariants of the noncommutative space. This geometric information encodes all the dynamics of the fundamental particles and their interactions and agrees with all experimental observations.
